node.title: Queen Elizabeth, calling for statesmanship, not politics, said ‘the time for action’ is now.
node.alt: A reception in Glasgow on Monday where attendees, including members of the royal family, top right, watched the queen’s video message.
node.description: The 95-year-old monarch gave her address by video, after doctors advised her to rest and not go to the summit. Prince Charles attended and delivered a similar message.
node.content: ["Queen Elizabeth II, absent from the climate summit because of health concerns but not silent, urged world leaders on Monday to rise above their current political differences and show true statesmanship for the sake of the planet.", "In a video message to the COP26 gathering in Glasgow, the 95-year-old monarch said that nations had overcome insurmountable problems and adversity throughout history by cooperating.", "\u201cIt has sometimes been observed that what leaders do for their people today is government and politics,\u201d she said. \u201cBut what they do for the people of tomorrow \u2014 that is statesmanship.\u201d", "The queen, wearing green and a butterfly brooch, had canceled her visit to Scotland on the advice of doctors because of what Buckingham Palace described as fatigue.", "She said that the environment had been a subject \u201cclose to the heart\u201d of her late husband, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, who died in April. Calling for world leaders to find common ground, she said that \u201cthe time for words has now moved to the time for action.\u201d", "\u201cOf course, the benefits of such actions will not be there to enjoy for all of us here today,\u201d she said. \u201cNone of us will live forever. But we are doing this not for ourselves, but for our children and our children\u2019s children, and those who will follow in their footsteps.\u201d", "The queen said that the environmental work of her late husband lived on through her eldest grandson, Prince William, and eldest son, Prince Charles, who, addressing world leaders on Monday at the summit, called for \u201ca military-style campaign\u201d to combat climate change.", "Charles\u2019s remarks built on comments on Sunday at the Group of 20 summit in Rome, where he described the conference as \u201cthe last-chance saloon\u201d to avoid the most severe effects from climate change.", "\u201cThe future of humanity and nature herself is at stake,\u201d said Charles, the Prince of Wales and heir to the British throne.", "\u201cIt is also impossible not to hear the despairing voices of young people who see you, ladies and gentlemen, as the stewards of the planet holding the viability of their future in your hands,\u201d he told world leaders assembled in Rome. He reminded them that they had an \u201coverwhelming responsibility to generations yet unborn.\u201d", "He said that adequately addressing climate change would require \u201ctrillions of dollars of investment every year to create the necessary new infrastructure and meet the vital 1.5 degree climate target that will save our forests and farms, our oceans and wildlife.\u201d"]
